qas.question: In 1960 did people believe an infant was able to remember things?

answers.text: Up until the middle of the 1980s it was assumed that infants could not encode, retain, and retrieve information.

qas.question: What is the minimum age researchers think a child begins to have memory?

answers.text: . A growing body of research now indicates that infants as young as 6-months can recall information

qas.question: Does a persons memory capacity increase with age?

answers.text: Furthermore, research has revealed that as infants grow older they can store information for longer periods of time

qas.question: Who has a better memory retention a 6 month old or a 9 month old?

plausible_answers.text: that infants could not encode, retain, and retrieve information

qas.question: What was assumed until the middle of the 1960s?
Research indicates that 6 month olds can recall what after a 48 hour delay?
6-month-olds need approximately five exposures in order to be able to do what?
What has shown that with age, infants can store information slower
as infants grow older they can store what for shorter periods of time?

context: <a0_0>Up until the middle of the 1980s it was assumed <b4_0>that infants could not encode, retain, and retrieve information<b4_0/><a1_0>.<a0_0/> A growing body of research now indicates that infants as young as 6-months can recall <b5_0>information<b5_0/><a1_0/> after a 24-hour delay. <a2_0>Furthermore, research has revealed that as infants grow older they can store <b8_0>information<b8_0/> for longer periods of time<a2_0/>; 6-month-olds can recall information after a 24-hour period, <a3_0>9-month-olds<a3_0/> after up to five weeks, and 20-month-olds after as long as twelve months. In addition, <b7_0>studies<b7_0/> have shown that with age, infants can store information faster. Whereas 14-month-olds can recall a three-step sequence after being exposed to it once, 6-month-olds need approximately six exposures in order to be able to <b6_0>remember it<b6_0/>.
